author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Farnsworth, Bay Chamber present Music@Noon
text:
Farnsworth, Bay Chamber present Music@Noon Oct 09, 2015 Spectrum Ensemble 
Rockland — Bay Chamber Concerts, in partnership with the Farnsworth Art Museum, will present the Spectrum Ensemble for the first concert of the season for the popular Music@Noon series Wednesday, Oct. 21. This special program of intimate concerts takes place at noon in the downtown museum’s library and includes a light lunch, an hour-long performance and free admission to the museum. 
Founded by cellist Frank Dodge in 1988, Berlin-based Spectrum Ensemble has attracted rave reviews both for its live performances at the Philharmonie/Kammermusiksaal and its many recordings. The group includes Joel Pritchon, violin; Ronald Carbone, viola; Frank Dodge, cello; Naomi Niskala, piano; Lucille Beer, contralto; and Lars Wouters van den Oudenweijer, clarinet. The Music@Noon program will feature work by Ernst Toch, Paul Hindemith, Johannes Brahms, Sergei Rachmaninoff and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart 
Now in its fourth season, Music@Noon, takes place on the third Wednesday of the month, with concerts scheduled for October, November, January, February and March. Ticket prices are $30, and $10 for those younger than 25; subscriptions for all five concerts are available for $120. All tickets may be purchased online at baychamberconcerts.org or by calling 236-2823. Sponsors for the Music @ Noon series are Allen Insurance and Financial and Ann B. Bixler. 
Ticketholders of the Oct. 21 Music@Noon concert also may attend the 6 p.m. Spectrum workshop presentation at Rockport’s Union Hall for free; admission will be $10 at the door for others. The “Forgotten Voices” evening is focused on Spectrum’s work in a school in Kosovo and will include a short film, discussion and live music. 
Courier Publications’ A&E Editor Dagney C. Ernest can be reached at (207) 594-4401, ext. 115; or dernest@courierpublicationsllc.com.
